Hi Carolina, 

Basically you can either keep the list of innovation numbers=
 for the 
current generation only or keep it forever. Try to experiment wit=
h 
each and then see what is best for your system. 

Perhaps searching for =
some older threads where the same issue is 
discussed will help you. 

Pete=
r

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Carolina Feher da Silva" 
<mirrorballu2@..=
.> wrote:
>
> It's been just a few months since I've started studying NEAT =
and I'm
> sorry if my question is very basic or has already been asked a lo=
t 
of
> times before (I've searched the group archive). I've been discussin=
g
> this with my friend and we don't understand how innovation numbers 
are=

> assigned to mutations.
> 
> Suppose a mutation links node n to node m. I=
f another mutation 
linking
> these nodes occurs in the same generation, th=
ey are both assigned 
the
> same innovation number, this part was clear. Bu=
t what if a mutation
> linking the same nodes occurs 100 generations later?=
 Is it assigned
> the same innovation number or a different one?
> 
> I've =
read Stanley's original C++ code and it seems that the new
> mutation is as=
signed a new innovation number, which makes sense to 
me,
> because the two=
 genes are not homologous and tracking homology among
> genes is the whole =
point of innovation numbers, right? But looking 
at
> a Python and a Java i=
mplementation, both have a global list of
> mutations and will assign the s=
ame innovation number to a mutation
> linking the same nodes. In this case,=
 don't innovation numbers 
become
> useless? All we need to know to align g=
enes for reproduction is 
which
> nodes are getting linked by a certain mut=
ation. Also we could be
> aligning genes that have completely different rol=
es in completely
> different network architectures. It seems wrong to me.
>=
 
> So does anyone know how this should be done and why?
> 
> Thanks,
> Car=
olina
>
